eu_initiatives:
As a result of its activities, UIA regularly broaches issues related in particular to the respect of rights within the European Union's normative framework, the new regulations proposed by its institutions and the decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union. 
 
These actions may take the form of: 
 
- Monitoring developments in European legislation in its areas of interest, in particular concerning the regulation of the legal profession, directly or indirectly (freedom of movement, fight against money laundering, fight against corruption, etc.), as well as subjects related to UIA-IROL's activities (access to justice and fundamental rights, migration and asylum, etc.) 
 
 Several of UIA's working commissions are particularly attentive to the latest regulations in their areas of expertise. That is particularly the case with the European Union's Law Commissions, Private International Law, Privacy and Digital Human Rights (e.g. Data Protection), Immigration and Nationality Law, Competition Law, Tax Law and Labour Law (see the UIA Commissions' website http://www.uianet.org/en/commissions ). 
 
- Preparation, dissemination and transmission of letters, information material, discussion papers and stands taken with regard to the above topics. 
 
- Direct contacts with members or officials of European institutions, especially to solicit them as speakers at our events.

UIA maintains close relations with various lawyers' organisations across the world, such as the American Bar Association (ABA) and its various sections, the Arab Lawyers' Union (ALU), the Council of Bars and Law Societies of Europe (CCBE), the International Bar Association Conference (CIB), the Inter-American Bar Association (IABA-FIA), the International Bar Association (IBA), the Inter-Pacific Bar Association (IPBA), the Law Association for Asia and the Pacific (LAWASIA), the Presidents of Law Associations in Asia (POLA), the Syracuse International Institute for Criminal Justice and Human Rights (SII) and the Unión Iberoamericana de Colegios y Agrupaciones de Abogados (UIBA). As part of this collaboration, it may prepare analytical documents, send letters or take a stand jointly on both professional issues and the specific subject of Human Rights. 
 
Likewise, UIA occasionally works with non-governmental human rights organisations.
goals__remit:
UIA (International Association of Lawyers) is a global and multicultural organisation for the legal profession.  
 
Established in 1927, it gathers today members from 120 countries. It facilitates professional development and international exchange of information and ideas, promotes the rule of law, defends the independence and freedom of lawyers worldwide, and emphasizes friendship, collegiality and networking among members.  
 
Multilingual and multicultural, UIA is open to all lawyers from the generalist or specialist world and also brings together bar presidents, legal professionals, in particular judges, business lawyers, notaries, professors and law students. 
 
The scope of UIA's actions extends beyond the interests of its members to cover the profession as a whole and contribute to the development of law internationally. 
 
- ACTIONS 
 
In all these missions, UIA pays particular attention to promoting and safeguarding the essential principles of the legal profession, in particular freedom and independence. To achieve its objectives, it promotes international contacts, cooperation and exchange of knowledge, while respecting the cultural and professional diversity of its members. 
 
- SCIENTIFIC ACTIVITIES 
 
UIA offers seminars, training and other events recognised as continuing education throughout the year and in various countries, and initiates high-level legal debates within its Commissions and Working Groups. 
 
- UIA-IROL 
 
Within UIA, the mission of the UIA-IROL (Institute of the Rule of Law) is to promote the rule of law, and address essential human rights issues. Access to justice, independence of the justice system and freedom and independence of the legal profession, being fundamental components of the rule of law, are also main issues of concern for the UIA-IROL.
